Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fluid-Structure Interaction and High-Performance Computing for Wind Energy Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rising costs and fluctuating prices of oil and natural gas, as well as their diminishing supplies, create the need for cheaper, sustainable alternative energy sources, such as wind. As a result, countries around the world are putting substantial effort into the development of wind energy technologies. The US Government established an ambitious goal of 25% electricity from wind by 2025, which may only be achieved with the help of leading-edge wind energy research, and which calls for transformative concepts and designs (e.g., floating offshore wind turbines) that must be created and analyzed with high-precision methods and tools. These include complex-geometry, 3D, time dependent, multi-physics predictive simulation methods and software that will play an increasingly important role as demand for wind energy grows.
The project focuses on the development of a fully integrated fluid-structure interaction software framework for computation of real wind turbine designs in 3D and at full spatial scale. Isogeometric Analysis is adopted as the over-arching geometry modeling and simulation technology due to its favorable geometry modeling properties, and superior pre-degree-of-freedom accuracy for the analysis of fluids and structures. The latter characteristic has great benefits from the standpoint of efficient utilization of high performance computing (HPC) resources.
The proposed computational framework is employed in the investigation of real-life, full-scale wind turbine designs. It is capable of addressing scientific and engineering challenges that are beyond the scope of the current simulation methods in the field. Ultimately, the methodology developed in this project is envisioned to become the ``gold standard" in wind turbine simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We were the first group to perform the FSI "full machine" simulation of a single wind turbine. We subsequently extended our modeling techniques to simulate multiple interacting wind-turbines. 

The sliding-interface formulation developed in the project, was esential in the simulation of single- and multiple-turbine cases. We expanded our reserch into the simulation of Vertical-Axis Wind Turbines (VAWTs) and were able to simulate two side-by-side counter-rotating turbines in order to examine the effect of their relative placement. The work on VAWTs is complemented with extensive experimental validation. 

We developed additional computational technology (structural mechanics and mesh moving techniques) and software for FSI simulations of Horizontal-Axis Wind Turbines (HAWTs) in yawing conditions in the presence of FSI: The turbine is spinning about its axis and simultaneously turns into the wind. This is a real-world situation and the simulations produced important information on blade dynamics and rotor loads due to this complicated combined action. Using the new techniques developed, we looked at VAWT start-up issues and were able to capture the phenomena observed in the field. 

We extended the FSI techniques to the case of offshore floating wind-turbine modeling and simulation. Additional complexities (compared to the on-land case) involved in the simulation of floating wind turbines are: 1. The presence of air-water coupling and their interaction with a flexible structure; 2. Handling of the interaction of the spinning rotor with the rest of the turbine undergoing large motions under the influence of ocean-wave forcing; 3. Convergence of coupled FSI equations in the presence of hydrodynamic loading. For the latter, the relatively simple block-iterative FSI coupling techniques that work very well in the on-land case are no longer suitable. A tighter quasi-direct coupling is necessary, which requires and additional formulation and clever implementation in the HPC environment. In addition to offshore wind, we began investigating the behavior of large wind turbines (>120~m rotor diameter) located in atmospheric boundary layers (ABLs). 

We published a good number of papers (a handful of which are ISI Highly Cited Papers!) and presented the work at international conferences. The PI gave several high-profile lectures (invited seminars and keynote and plenary and semi-plenary talks at international conferences). We also organized minisymposia focusing on FSI and wind modeling at international conferences. Graduate-level Classes as well as Short Cousres were developed based on the reserch generated in the project.

A surface model of a 5MW blade used in the project was developed and shared with the community for benchmarking purposes.

The project provided training for several highly talented graduate students that went to successful careers in academia and national labs.
